page.title: 01RURAL AREA OF THE SOUTH HAMS
page.content: This block, which is very typical of the hinterland of the South Hams Area of Devon, lying as it does between the cliff-lined coast and the swelling uplands of Dartmoor, consists of an upland plateau 400 to 500 feet high, divided by deep narrow combes, well wooded, and each with its little stream, hurrying down to the sea. Other than in the combes trees are sparse and 95 per cent at least of the area is grassland, devoted in the main to sheep, but with about 30 per cent cattle. Land under cereals amounts to no more than 5 per cent. The block has only one hamlet, Brownston, very small, but pre-norman. Twentieth century incursions into the area consist of one petrol filling station on the site of the Old Smithy and three caravan sites, though many of the farms take in summer visitors.
